hero_description: Design multi-stage transmissions of any complexity. Assemble gear cascades, set your parameters, and get instant calculations. An automatically generated kinematic schematic helps you visualize and lay out your transmission.
changelog_v1_2_changes_1: Added full localization for the application in 7 languages.
changelog_v1_2_changes_2: Implemented cloud project saving upon authorization.
changelog_v1_2_changes_3: Added the ability to share a project via a link.
changelog_v1_1_changes_2: Reworked the local project saving system.
changelog_v1_0_changes_1: First public release of the application.
feedback_success_message: Thank you! Your feedback has been sent.
feedback_error_message: An error occurred. Please try again.
workbench_add_new_stage: Add a new stage at this location
workbench_add_variant_tooltip: Add a new gear variant to this stage
workbench_add_variant_disabled_tooltip: A planetary, bevel, or worm gear must be the only variant in a stage.
efficiency_desc_chain: Depends on lubrication and wear. Can drop to 0.9 in poor conditions.
efficiency_desc_planetary: High efficiency due to load distribution among several planet gears.
efficiency_desc_toothed_belt: Requires no lubrication but is sensitive to tension.
efficiency_desc_belt: Depends on tension and slippage. V-belts typically have slightly lower efficiency.
efficiency_desc_bevel: For straight-tooth bevel gears. Spiral teeth can increase efficiency.
efficiency_desc_worm: Highly dependent on the lead angle (Œ≥) and friction. Can be significantly lower for self-locking gears.
notification_copy_error: Copy error. Please ensure your browser allows clipboard access.
notification_paste_error: Clipboard does not contain valid data or an error occurred.
notification_config_reset: Configuration has been reset to default values.
notification_paste_error_single_only: Cannot paste a turning or planetary gear into a stage with multiple variants.
notification_paste_error_parallel_on_sin: Cannot paste this gear type into a stage that already contains a turning or planetary gear.
calc_param_warning_amin: WARNING: This is the theoretical distance based on pitch diameters. The actual distance (based on outer diameters + clearance) will be greater.
calc_param_warning_tb_amin: WARNING: This is a theoretical distance based on pulley pitch diameters. The actual center distance will depend on the chosen belt and required tension.
calc_param_warning_belt_amin: WARNING: This is a theoretical distance based on pulley design diameters. The actual center distance will depend on the belt type, length, and required tension.
dialog_rebuild_scheme_message: Are you sure you want to rebuild the schematic? All manual layout changes will be lost.
tooltip_build_scheme_disabled: You must save the project before building a schematic
tooltip_rebuild_scheme: Re-create the schematic from scratch using the current parameters
tooltip_build_scheme: Assemble a kinematic schematic based on the selected gear types

validation_interference_z_diff: Small tooth difference (zR-zP < 10); interference is possible

cascade_error_no_selection: No gear variant selected in Stage {stageName}.
notification_at_least_one_module_configu: At least one gear module must be configured.
dialog_missing_params_warning_message: Warning: Gear parameters are incomplete. The schematic will be built as a basic kinematic layout, without accurate dimensions or gear ratios. The scale of the components will be representational. Continue?
dialog_structural_changes_message: You have changed a gear type (e.g., from parallel to angular), or added/removed a stage. These changes conflict with the current schematic layout. Please choose an action:
dialog_structural_changes_revert_button: Revert Changes and Return to Schematic
dialog_revert_changes_message: Are you sure? All unsaved changes in the Workbench will be lost.
dialog_session_restore_message: Would you like to restore your previous session? If you decline, unsaved data will be lost.
guide_retake_tour_title: Need a refresher? You can retake the interactive tour.
guide_intro_p1: This web application is a tool for the preliminary design and calculation of multi-stage transmissions and their visualization as kinematic schematics. The workflow is divided into two main parts:
guide_intro_li1: The Workbench: This is the control center where you enter all numerical data, configure transmission stages, and analyze the results.
guide_intro_li2: The Schematic Builder: A visual workspace where you assemble the kinematic schematic, manage the spatial arrangement of components, and prepare it for export.
guide_general_tips_p1: Here are a few useful features to make your work more convenient:
guide_general_tips_li1: Autosave: Your work is automatically saved in your browser. If you accidentally close the tab, the application will offer to restore your session on your next visit.
guide_general_tips_li2: Tooltips: Not sure what a parameter means? Click on its name (e.g., z‚ÇÅ) to see a detailed explanation.
guide_general_tips_li3: Interactive Tour: You can always restart the tutorial from this help window to refresh your memory on the main features.
guide_workbench_p1: All the mathematical calculations happen on this screen. It is organized into several key panels.
guide_workbench_source_p1: Here, you define the initial conditions for the entire transmission: input torque, RPM range, and initial direction of rotation. This data is the starting point for all subsequent calculations.
guide_workbench_stages_li1: A stage is a pair of shafts (e.g., "Shafts 1 and 2") between which power is transmitted. You can add more stages to extend the kinematic chain.
guide_workbench_stages_li2: A gear card represents a specific type of transmission (spur gear, chain drive, etc.) within a stage. You can add multiple variants to one stage for comparison, but only the one marked as "Primary" is used in the final calculation.
guide_workbench_stages_li3: Limitation: Turning gears (bevel, worm) and planetary gears must be the only variant in their stage.
guide_workbench_config_li1: Select the gear type (spur, chain, planetary, etc.). Each type has its own set of parameters.
guide_workbench_config_li2: Click on a parameter's name (e.g., z‚ÇÅ) to see a detailed tooltip.
guide_workbench_config_li3: For a basic calculation, you only need to fill in the minimum required parameters (e.g., number of teeth, pulley diameters).
guide_workbench_config_li4: In the expandable "Details" section, you can input additional parameters like module, pitch, and efficiency for more precise calculations. Here, you'll also find all derived parameters (diameters, center distance) and cascade characteristics (torque and RPM at the stage input and output).
guide_workbench_config_li5: Calculations update in real-time as you make changes. Fields with errors are highlighted in red, and warnings in yellow.
guide_workbench_config_li6: The menu (three dots) on each module card allows you to copy and paste parameters, speeding up work with similar gears.
guide_workbench_final_p1: This panel dynamically displays the final characteristics of the entire transmission, taking into account all "Primary" variants from each stage.
guide_workbench_note_p1: It's possible to build a schematic without completing all calculations. If you only select the gear types without specifying their parameters, default values will be used to draw the diagram.
guide_scheme_p1: Once your calculations are set, proceed to the builder to visualize and arrange your transmission.
guide_scheme_nav_p1: Pan the canvas by holding down the left mouse button and zoom with the mouse wheel. Use the on-screen controls for quick zooming and fitting the schematic to the view.
guide_scheme_menu_p1: Clicking any element (a standard graphical symbol) on the schematic opens its context menu. This menu displays key parameters and provides layout options.
guide_scheme_menu_li1: For parallel-axis gears, you can invert the layout and change the direction of the output shaft.
guide_scheme_menu_li2: For turning gears, you can select the output direction.
guide_scheme_menu_li3: You can quickly navigate between the menus of adjacent elements using the ‚Üê and ‚Üí buttons.
guide_scheme_collision_p1: If symbols overlap, they will be highlighted in red. Use spacer shafts (added via the context menu) to increase the distance between components and resolve overlaps. The style and length of the spacer can be configured in its own menu.
guide_scheme_sync_p1: If you make changes in the Workbench that conflict with the current layout (e.g., changing a gear from parallel to angular), a dialog will appear when you return to the schematic:
guide_scheme_sync_li1: "Apply and Rebuild Schematic": This applies all changes from the Workbench but completely resets any manual layout adjustments you've made. It is similar to clicking the main "Rebuild Schematic (Resets Layout)" button.
guide_scheme_sync_li2: "Revert Changes and Return to Schematic": This discards all changes made in the Workbench and restores the previous saved schematic layout. The data in the Workbench and the schematic will be synchronized again.
guide_scheme_sync_li3: If your changes do not conflict with the structure, the parameters on the schematic will update automatically upon your return.
guide_scheme_sync_li4: The reset button (eraser icon) discards all layout changes and returns the schematic to its original, auto-generated state.
guide_export_p1: The "Project & Export" menu (folder icon) is your hub for managing saves and exporting results.
guide_export_management_li1: Local Projects: Save projects directly in your browser. They will be available in the list on your next visit from the same device.
guide_export_management_li2: Cloud Sync: Sign in with your account (via Google) to save projects to the cloud. This allows you to work on them across different devices and serves as a reliable backup.
guide_export_management_li3: Sharing: Projects saved to the cloud can be made public by generating a unique link to send to colleagues.
guide_export_management_li4: Working with Files (.json): Use the "Save to File" and "Load from File" options to exchange projects or create manual backups.
guide_export_reports_li1: PDF: Creates a full report, including the kinematic schematic and all tables with initial, intermediate, and final data. Ideal for documentation.
guide_export_reports_li2: CSV: Exports all calculation data in a spreadsheet format for opening in Excel or Google Sheets.
guide_export_reports_li3: SVG/PNG: Saves only an image of the kinematic schematic in vector (SVG) or raster (PNG) format for use in presentations or other documents.
project_modal_dirty_warning: You have unsaved changes in the project '{projectName}'.
project_modal_signin_prompt: Sign in to save projects to the cloud and sync them across devices.
project_modal_signin_required_tooltip: Sign in to access cloud features

Exporting a full PDF report that includes the schematic is only available from the 'Schematic Builder' page.

To export only the calculation data, please use the CSV format.

notification_share_data_not_found: Project data not found in the cloud.
notification_projects_update_error_offli: Failed to load cloud projects: No internet connection.
dialog_delete_project_message: This action cannot be undone. The project will be deleted locally and from the cloud.
dialog_delete_local_copy_message: The cloud copy, if it exists, will not be affected.
dialog_delete_cloud_copy_message: The local copy, if it exists, will not be affected.
conflict_modal_message: For the following projects, the local and cloud versions differ. Please choose which version you want to keep.
notification_conflict_resolve_success: Conflict for project "{projectName}" has been resolved.
notification_conflict_resolve_error_offl: Could not resolve conflict: no internet connection or you are not signed in.
notification_conflict_resolve_error_sync: Synchronization error. Please check your connection and try again.
scheme_overlap_warning: Component overlap detected. Use spacer shafts to resolve the collision.
tour_workbench_intro: This short tour will introduce you to the main features of the transmission calculator. Let's get started!
tour_workbench_step2_intro: Define the input torque and RPM range from your motor or other power source.
tour_workbench_step3_intro: A transmission consists of stages. Each stage represents a power transfer between two shafts. Use this button to add a new stage.
tour_workbench_step4_intro: Add a gear variant to the stage. You can add several parallel-axis variants (spur, chain, belt) for comparison, but turning and planetary gears must be the only variant in a stage.
tour_workbench_step5_intro: Select the gear type and enter its primary parameters. For this demo, we'll automatically fill in some values.
tour_workbench_step6_intro: Here you can see the calculated parameters (center distance, diameters, etc.) and the stage's input/output characteristics. All data updates in real-time.
tour_workbench_step7_intro: Once you enter the data, the final parameters for the entire transmission are shown here. Keep an eye on this block to evaluate your design.
tour_workbench_step8_intro: When your configuration is ready, click 'Build Schematic' to move to the visual editor.
tour_scheme_intro: This is where you can visually assemble your transmission. This tour will guide you through the basics.
tour_scheme_step2_intro: Pan the view by holding the left mouse button and zoom with the mouse wheel. You can also use these controls to manage the view.
tour_scheme_step3_intro: Clicking on any element on the schematic, like this input source, opens its context menu.
tour_scheme_step4_intro: The menu allows you to view information, add a spacer shaft, or quickly jump back to its parameters in the Workbench.
tour_scheme_step5_intro: Use these buttons to reset the schematic layout or open the project menu to save and export your results.
tour_scheme_step6_intro: This button will take you back to the Workbench to edit your calculation parameters.
tour_scheme_final_intro: You're now ready to start designing. Experiment with the layout to achieve your desired result!
